Company: AIG Federal Savings Bank and Wilmington Finance Inc.
Description: Two subsidiaries of American International Group Inc. agreed to pay a minimum of $6.1 million to resolve allegations that they engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination against African American borrowers.
American International Group, Inc. agreed to pay a $100 million penalty and $700 million in disgorgement to settle allegations of securities fraud.

American International Group, Inc. and two of its subsidiaries agreed to resolve the criminal liability associated with certain financial transactions by paying $80 million in penalties to the United States and cooperating fully in the government's continuing criminal investigation of those transactions.

American International Group, Inc. agreed to pay $46 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest to settle the SEC portion of a fraud case arising out of AIG's offer and sale of an earnings management product.

American International Group, Inc. (AIG) has agreed to resolve criminal liability arising from misstatements in its periodic financial reports filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission between 2000 and 2004 by paying $25 million in penalties to the United States and cooperating fully in the government's continuing criminal investigation.

American International Group, Inc. agreed to pay $10 million to settle allegations relating to its role in fashioning and selling a purported insurance product that Brightpoint Inc. used to report false and misleading financial information to the public.

Private Litigation Case Title: In re American International Group, Inc. ERISA Litigation II

Description: American International Group paid an additional $900,000 for reconciliations of premiums not yet paid out. The payment is part of an ongoing reconciliation of premiums and residual market payouts stemming from the insurer's settlement of Big Dig workers compensation insurance premium issues with the Attorney General's Office.
AIG paid an extra $218,920 to the Central Artery Tunnel Project as part of its ongoing settlement of Big Dig workers compensation insurance premium issues.

The Massachusetts Attorney General reached a $58.5 million settlement with American International Group, the workers' compensation carrier for the Central Artery Tunnel Project, known as the Big Dig. A review by the Attorney General's Office had found that the company failed to pay certain surplus funds to the Commonwealth as required under its contract.
Info Source: AG Coakley Recovers $58.5 Million from Big Dig Insurer, States News Service, May 14, 2007 (via Nexis).

Description: AIG agreed to a settlement with the New York Attorney General and the federal government worth more than $1.6 billion to resolve allegations of fraud, bid-rigging and improper accounting. Of the total, $800 million was to go to investors deceived by false financial statements, $375 million to AIG policyholders harmed by bid rigging activities and $344 million to states harmed by AIG's practices between 1986 and 1995 involving workers' compensation funds. In addition, New York imposed a $100 million penalty against the company. The SEC issued its own announcement about the $800 million portion of the settlement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-american-international-group-inc-1
The Ohio Attorney General announed a $725 million settlement with American International Group in a securities class action brought on behalf of three Ohio state pension funds and other investors.
Info Source: Cordray Secures Record Settlement with AIG, Targeted News Service, July 16, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: AIG agreed to pay $9 million to Ohio to settle allegations that it conspired with insurance broker Marsh & McLennan and other insurers to eliminate competition in the commercial casualty insurance industry.
AIG agreed to pay $8 million to settle allegations that investment losses expeirnced by Oregon's public pension funds were attributable to a pattern of poor disclosure and bid-rigging by AIG.

AIG agreed to pay $12.5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it participated in bid-rigging, price-fixing and other anti-competitive practices in the sale of commercial insurance services.
underpayment of workers compensation premium taxes

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined Arch Insurance Company $1 million and National Union Fire Insurance Company $1.2 million and ordered the insurers to provide a combined $8 million in retroactive rebates for violations of New York Insurance Law following an investigation that found both insurers failed to satisfy required minimum loss ratio standards in blanket accident and health insurance policies issued to hundreds of New York volunteer firefighter districts, departments and companies. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay in rebates. Here we assume the total was equally divided between them.

Description: American General agreed to pay $7.5 million to regulators in five states to resolve allegations that it charged black customers more than whites for burial policies.

AIG agreed to pay $100 million in fines, plus $46.5 million in taxes and assessments, to insurance regulators in all 50 states and the District of Columbia for under-reporting its workers compensation premiums before 1996 and thus may not have paid its fair share of the workers comp residual market.
Info Source: AIG to Pay $146.5 Million to Settle State Allegations of Under Reporting Workers' Comp Premiums, Bestwire, December 23, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: AIG and various subsidiaries agreed to pay $11 million to a group of states to resolve litigation relating to their use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.

Company: National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh, PA
Description: National Union Fire agreed to pay $39 million to resolve litigation brought by a group of state insurance regulators after an investigation found problems relating to matters such as rate and form filings; actuarial procedures and premium allocation; licensing of agents and claims personnel; claims processing; vendor oversight; training of personnel; handling of consumer complaints; use of trusts, record retention, IT issues, among others.

Company: National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh, PA
Description: National Union Fire Insurance Co. agreed to pay a $106,000 fine following a Market Conduct Examination finding it conducted insurance business using unlicensed entities or agents in violation of statutory requirements.

Description: AIG agreed to pay a $12 million penalty in settlement of alleged violations of New York Insurance Law by a subsidiary doing pension risk transfer business in the state without a license.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Houston-based VALIC Financial Advisors, Inc., a total of $1.75 million for failing to identify and reasonably address certain conflicts of interest in the firm's compensation policy for instances when customers elected to move assets out of their VALIC variable annuities (VA), many of which were held in retirement plan accounts. The firm also failed to adequately supervise its VA business, including the sale of VAs with multiple share classes.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: FINRA fined 25 broker-dealers a total of $2,145,000 for failures related to their completion of FINRA's (then NASD's) firm self-assessment of mutual fund breakpoint discount compliance.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling more than $34 million on 15 broker-dealers in connection with the receipt of directed brokerage in exchange for preferential treatment for certain mutual fund companies
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
